questions.question: Which of the following is not a first-generation cephalosporin?
questions.explanation: Cefaclor is not a first-generation cephalosporin. It is a second-generation oral cephalosporin. First-generation cephalosporins are: oral formulations, such as Cefadroxil, Cephalexin, and Cephradine; and parenteral formulation, such as cefazolin.

questions.question: A patient is undergoing orthopedic surgery. Which of the following first-generationcephalosporins can you use for surgical prophylaxis?
questions.explanation: The first-generation cephalosporin indicated for surgical prophylaxis is Cefazolin. It is thepreferred agent for surgical prophylaxis when skin flora is the likely pathogen.Cephalexin, cefadroxil, and cephradine are first-generation oral cephalosporins.

questions.question: You want to prescribe an oral second-generation cephalosporin to a patient with pneumonia.Which of the following drugs will you choose?
questions.explanation: Cefaclor is a second-generation oral cephalosporin.Option A: Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin.Options B and D: Cefadroxil and Cephradine are oral first-generation cephalosporins.

questions.question: In comparison with first-generation cephalosporins, second-generation cephalosporins havewhich of the following properties?

options.A: Greater activity against gram positive bacteria502
options.B: Lesser activity against gram positive bacteria

questions.explanation: Second-generation cephalosporins have lesser activity against gram-positive bacteria whencompared with first-generation cephalosporins.Properties of second-generation cephalosporins, when compared to first-generationcephalosporins, are:• Lesser activity against gram-positive bacteria•Broader gram-negative activity against Hemophilus species, indole-positive Proteus, andKlebsiella species• Anaerobes like B.fragilis are susceptible to second-generation cephalosporins like cefoxitin andcefotetan but not first-generation cephalosporins

questions.question: Which of the following is a third-generation cephalosporin that can be given orally?
Cephalosporins are not useful in which of the following infections?
questions.explanation: Ampicillin is the drug of choice for listeriosis, which is caused by Listeria monocytogenes, andcephalosporins are not useful in treating this condition.Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, which is considered as a treatment of choice forgonorrhea and severe forms of Lyme disease.Cefoperazone and ceftazidime are third-generation cephalosporins that have clinically significantactivity against Pseudomonas.CephalosporinsFirst-generationonTherapeutic usesSkin and soft tissue infectionsSerious infections due to MSSAPerioperative surgical prophylaxisSecond generati Upper respiratory tract infections (sinusitis, otitis media)Cefoxitin/cefotetan - gynecologic infections, perioperative surgical prophylaxisThird generationCommunity-acquired pneumonia, meningitis, urinary tract infectionsStreptococcal endocarditisGonorrheaSevere Lyme disease

questions.question: Thepus culture and sensitivity report of a hospitalized patient with diabetic ulcer is positivefor pseudomonas. Which of the following cephalosporins can be used in this patient?
questions.explanation: The drug that can be used in this patient is Ceftazidime, which is a third-generation parenteralcephalosporin having significant anti-pseudomonal action.Cefpodoxime proxetil is a third-generation oral cephalosporin. It does not have significantantipseudomonal action.Cephradine and cefotetan are first and second-generation cephalosporins with noantipseudomonal action.Antipseudomonal cell wall synthesis inhibitors are:•Cephalosporins:• Third generation - Ceftazidime, Cefoperazone⚫ Fourth generation - Cefepime and cefpirome. They are also used against enterobacter• Fifth generation - Ceftolozane509• Extended-spectrum penicillins:• Carboxypenicillins carbenicillin, ticarcillin•-Ureidopenicillins - piperacillin, mezlocillin

questions.question: Which of the following statements about cefepime is false?

options.B: Dose should be reduced in renal failure

questions.explanation: Cefepime, which is a fourth-generation cephalosporin, has good activity againstPseudomonas, Enterobacter, and S. aureus, but not against MRSA. It is effective in seriousinfections like hospital-acquired pneumonia, septicemia and febrile neutropenia.Cefepime is excreted primarily through kidneys and dose reduction is necessary for renalfailure. Encephalopathy and non-convulsive status epilepticus have been reported with the use ofcefepime.

questions.question: A 34-year-old man presents with a discharging wound post-operatively. Cultures revealinfection with MRSA. Which of the following cephalosporins can be used for this patient?
questions.explanation: Ceftaroline is the cephalosporin that is indicated for MRSA infections and hence can be used inthis patient. It is considered as anti-MRSA cephalosporin and along with ceftobiprole is groupedas fifth-generation cephalosporins.Ceftaroline has gram-negative and also enhanced gram-positive coverage. It is effectiveagainst MRSA and penicillin-resistant S. pneumoniae.Cefepime and cefpirome are fourth-generation cephalosporins with no significant action onMRSA.Ceftolozane is a fifth-generation antipseudomonal cephalosporin with no action on MRSA.

questions.question: A patient is to be started on a cephalosporin antibiotic. His serum creatinine levels yesterdayat the time of admission was 1.1 mg/dl and now it is 1.5 mg/dl. Which of the followingcephalosporins can be started without dose reduction in this patient?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of acute kidney injury and the cephalosporin that does notrequire dose reduction in this patient is cefoperazone.All cephalosporins are usually excreted by glomerular filtration and tubular secretion. They need adose reduction in renal failure, except cefpiramide and cefoperazone that have predominantbiliary excretion.Dose reduction is necessary for cefoperazone and cefpiramide in patients with hepaticimpairment.

questions.question: What is the drug of choice for a patient who presents with an initial episode of Clostridiumdifficile infection?
questions.explanation: The drug of choice for the treatment of initial episode of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) isfidaxomicin. It is a macrocyclic antibiotic.510Fidaxomicin is preferred because of its safety profile and higher beneficial effects. But inresource-limited settings where it is not available, vancomycin can be used for the treatment ofthis condition.Treatment of Clostridium difficile infection:• Fidaxomicin• Vancomycin• MetronidazoleVancomycin and fidaxomicin are more effective than metronidazole. All of the above drugs aregiven orally.Loracarbef is a second-generation cephalosporin and is not indicated in pseudomembranouscolitis caused by Clostridium difficile.NOTE:Asper the Infectious Disease Society of America (IDSA) management guidelines 2021,Fidaxomicin is now preferred over Vancomycin for the treatment of initial episode of Clostridiumdifficile infection. Vancomycin can be used as an alternative drug.

questions.question: 504What is the mechanism of action of vancomycin?
questions.explanation: The mechanism of action of vancomycin is cell wall synthesis inhibition.The bacterial cell wall has long chains of peptidoglycan and is cross-linked to each other by theaction of the enzyme transglycosylase. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide group of antibiotics thatbinds to the D-alanyl-D-alanine terminus of the synthesized peptidoglycan. This inhibits thetransglycosylase enzyme and prevents elongation and cross-linking of peptidoglycan. This leads tothe weakening of the cell wall causing lysis.It exhibits a time-dependant or concentration-independent killing of bacteria. It primarily acts onGram +ve organisms which are resistant to other antibiotics such as methicillin-resistantstaphylococcus and ampicillin resistant enterococci.Lipoglycopeptides are a new generation of glycopeptide congeners which include telavancin,dalbavancin, and oritavancin. Dalbavancin and Oritovancin are administered as a singleintravenous dose for skin and soft-tissue infections.511Cell wall synthesis inhibitors-Site of actionCycloserineN-acetylmuramic acidBacitracinCytoplasm of cellPeptideN-acetylglucosamineVancomycinPenicillinsLOWCephalosporinsCell wall forms:OMARROWCross-linking ofpeptide molecules

questions.question: Oral vancomycin is used in the treatment of:
questions.explanation: Oral vancomycin is used in the treatment of Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea andstaphylococcal enterocolitis.Its oral formulation is not absorbed systemically and hence is used for local action in thegastrointestinal tract.

questions.question: A patient on intravenous vancomycin develops flushing and erythematous lesions. Onexamination, tachycardia, and hypotension are noted. By what mechanism does vancomycincause these effects?

options.B: Direct toxic effect on mast cells

questions.explanation: The given scenario depicts red man syndrome associated with vancomycin. It occurs due to adirect toxic effect on mast cells resulting in the release of histamine.Red man or red neck syndrome is a non-allergic reaction due to rapid intravenous infusion ofvancomycin characterized by:• Flushing• Erythematous, urticarial reactions• Tachycardia•⚫ HypotensionSlow infusion, prophylactic use of antihistamines can reduce the incidence.

questions.question: Match the following bacteria with the drug of choice for each.
questions.explanation: Vancomycin is the drug of choice for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Itshould be used only if the organism is resistant to other drugs.512Metronidazole is the drug of choice for anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.Metronidazole is used in the treatment of the following conditions:• Giardiasis• Trichomoniasis•• Amoebiasis• Bacterial vaginosis• Pseudomembranous colitisMeropenem is used in infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria like Klebsiella.Carbapenems are not hydrolyzed by ESBL (extended-spectrum beta-lactamases). Therefore,carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem and ertapenem are resistant to hydrolysis by ESBLs.They are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria,like Klebsiella and E. coli.Penicillins like amoxicillin, ampicillin can be used in H. influenzae infections.

questions.question: 505A patient allergic to penicillin requires antibiotic therapy. Which of the following can yousafely prescribe?
questions.explanation: Aztreonam can be safely given to a patient with a history of allergy to penicillin. It is amonobactam group of ẞ-Lactam antibiotics resistant to narrow-spectrum beta-lactamaseproduced by bacteria.It lacks cross-sensitivity with the other beta-lactams, except for ceftazidime. It has activity onlyagainst gram-negative bacteria. It has no activity against gram-positive bacteria and anaerobes.

questions.question: Which of the following carbapenems has increased risk of causing seizures?
questions.explanation: Imipenem is the carbapenem that is associated with an increased risk of causing seizures,especially when high doses are given to patients with CNS lesions.Excretion of imipenem is mainly renal and dosage modification is required to avoid seizures inrenal failure patients.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about extended-spectrum beta-lactamases?They can hydrolyse penicillins, cephalosporins as well as monobactamb) Carbapenems are hydrolysed by ESBLc) Ambler classification of ESBL is based on amino acidsequenced) Third and fourth generation cephalosporins are used for detection of ESBLQuestion 19:Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation: Carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem are resistant to hydrolysis byextended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBL) and hence are indicated in the treatment of infectionscaused by ESBL producing bacteria.Beta-lactamases are enzymes produced by bacteria that are able to hydrolyze antibiotics and makethem ineffective, thus making the bacteria resistant to these antibiotics. They confer resistanceagainst:513• Penicillins•Cephalosporins• MonobactamsBeta lactamases hydrolyze first and second-generation cephalosporins but are ineffective againstthird and fourth-generation.Beta lactamases are classified into four categories based on their amino acid sequences, by theAmbler classification.ESBLs also hydrolyze third and fourth-generation cephalosporins - cefotaxime, ceftazidime,ceftriaxone and cefepime.
